species.name: Almond Mushroom
species.description: The Almond Mushroom (Agaricus subrufescens), also known as Agaricus blazei, Himematsutake or Cogumelo de Deus, is an edible mushroom with an intense almond aroma. Originally discovered in the rainforests of Brazil, it is today one of the most important medicinal mushrooms worldwide. It possesses the highest concentration of beta-glucans of all medicinal mushrooms and is intensively studied for its immunomodulatory and antitumoral properties. Remarkably successful studies on its healing effects have been conducted in Japan and the USA.

species.name: Aloe Vera
species.description: Aloe vera is a succulent plant species of the genus Aloe. It originates from the Arabian Peninsula but grows wild in tropical, semi-tropical, and arid climates around the world. The species is cultivated for agricultural and medicinal uses. The plant's gel-filled leaves have been used for thousands of years in traditional medicine to treat wounds, burns, and skin conditions. It is one of the most commercially important medicinal plants worldwide.

species.name: Arabica Coffee
species.description: Coffea arabica, known as Arabica coffee, is a species of flowering plant in the family Rubiaceae. Native to the highlands of Ethiopia and South Sudan, it is believed to be the first species of coffee to be cultivated. Arabica accounts for approximately 60-70% of global coffee production and is considered to produce superior quality coffee compared to Coffea canephora (Robusta). The plant requires specific growing conditions including high altitude, consistent rainfall, and temperatures between 15-24 degrees Celsius.

species.name: Artist's Bracket
species.description: The Artist's Bracket (Ganoderma applanatum), also known as Artist's Conk, is a perennial bracket fungus with a characteristically flat, shelf-like shape. Its name derives from the property of the white pore surface, which permanently stains brown when touched - allowing pictures to be drawn on it. The fungus causes white rot in hardwoods. In Traditional Chinese Medicine it is used as a medicinal mushroom.

species.name: Ashwagandha
species.description: Withania somnifera, commonly known as ashwagandha, Indian ginseng, or winter cherry, is a plant in the Solanaceae family native to India and Southeast Asia. It has been a cornerstone of Ayurvedic medicine for over 3000 years, used as a rasayana (rejuvenating tonic). The name ashwagandha is Sanskrit for 'smell of the horse', referring to both the root's odor and its traditional use to impart strength. The root contains withanolides, which have adaptogenic properties, helping the body cope with stress. Modern clinical trials have shown benefits for anxiety, stress, and cognitive function.

species.name: Asian Ginseng
species.description: Panax ginseng, commonly known as Asian ginseng, Korean ginseng, or Chinese ginseng, is a species of plant whose root has been used in traditional Chinese medicine for over 2000 years. The genus name Panax is derived from the Greek word 'panacea', meaning 'all-healing', reflecting its historical reputation. The root contains ginsenosides, which are believed to be responsible for its adaptogenic properties, helping the body resist stress. Wild ginseng is extremely rare and valuable, with roots selling for thousands of dollars. Cultivation takes 4-6 years before harvest.

species.name: Birch Polypore
species.description: The Birch Polypore (Fomitopsis betulina) is a well-known medicinal mushroom that grows exclusively on birch trees. Historically significant is the find with the Iceman (Oetzi), who carried two pieces of this fungus with him. In folk medicine it has been used for millennia against gastrointestinal complaints, for wound healing and as an anti-inflammatory. Modern studies confirm antibacterial, antiviral and antitumoral properties.
species.seo_description: Birch Polypore (Fomitopsis betulina). Heilwirkung: Gastrointestinal complaints, Wound healing

species.name: Bitter Oyster
species.description: The Bitter Oyster (Panellus stipticus) is a small, shell-shaped fungus that grows on hardwood. It is particularly notable for its bioluminescence - the mycelium and young fruiting bodies glow greenish in the dark. The fungus is inedible due to its bitter-pungent taste. The bioluminescence is based on the substances PS-A and PS-B (luciferin precursors).

species.name: Blue Oyster
species.description: The Blue Oyster (Pleurotus columbinus) is a variant of the oyster mushroom with characteristic blue-gray cap color. It grows preferentially on conifer wood and is cultivated year-round. Like other Pleurotus species, it contains pleurotolysin which is destroyed by heating - therefore always cook thoroughly. It has immunostimulating and cholesterol-lowering properties.

species.name: Ceylon Cinnamon
species.description: Cinnamomum verum, also called true cinnamon or Ceylon cinnamon, is a small evergreen tree native to Sri Lanka. The inner bark is used to make cinnamon, one of the oldest known spices. It was so highly prized among ancient nations that it was regarded as a gift fit for monarchs. Ceylon cinnamon is distinguished from cassia cinnamon by its lighter color, more delicate flavor, and lower coumarin content, making it safer for regular consumption. The spice contains cinnamaldehyde, which has antimicrobial and blood sugar-regulating properties.

species.name: Chaga
species.description: The Chaga (Inonotus obliquus) is an important medicinal mushroom that is traditionally used especially in Russia and Northern Europe. The fungus forms black, coal-like growths (sclerotia) on living birch trees. Its antioxidant, immunostimulating and antitumoral properties have been valued for centuries. It is considered one of the strongest antioxidants among mushrooms.

species.name: Chanterelle
species.description: The Chanterelle (Cantharellus cibarius), also called Golden Chanterelle, is one of the most popular and well-known edible mushrooms in Europe. With its egg-yolk yellow color, fruity aroma and slightly peppery taste, it is highly prized in cuisine. As a mycorrhizal fungus, it grows in symbiosis with trees in mixed forests. Chanterelles contain antiviral, antioxidant and antibiotic compounds.

species.description: The Chicken of the Woods (Laetiporus sulphureus), also called Sulphur Shelf, is a striking, sulfur-yellow to orange colored bracket fungus. It grows mainly on hardwoods and is an aggressive wood decomposer causing brown rot. When young it is a good edible mushroom with chicken-like taste, but becomes tough with age. It is indigestible raw due to oxalic acid.

species.name: Common Dandelion
species.description: Taraxacum officinale, commonly known as the common dandelion, is a flowering herbaceous perennial plant in the family Asteraceae. Native to Eurasia, it has naturalized worldwide. Though often considered a weed, dandelion is a valuable medicinal and culinary plant. Every part of the plant is edible and nutritious. The leaves are used in salads, the roots can be roasted as a coffee substitute, and the flowers are used to make wine. Medicinally, dandelion is a powerful diuretic (hence the French name pissenlit) and liver tonic. It contains taraxacin, inulin, and high levels of vitamins A, C, and K.

species.name: Common Sage
species.description: Salvia officinalis, commonly known as sage, common sage, or garden sage, is a perennial evergreen subshrub native to the Mediterranean region. It has been cultivated for culinary and medicinal purposes for thousands of years. The name Salvia derives from the Latin 'salvare', meaning 'to save' or 'to heal', reflecting its historical importance in traditional medicine. Sage contains rosmarinic acid, carnosic acid, and thujone, and is used to improve memory, reduce inflammation, and treat digestive disorders.

species.name: Common Thyme
species.description: Thymus vulgaris, commonly known as common thyme or garden thyme, is a species of flowering plant in the mint family Lamiaceae, native to southern Europe. It is a low-growing aromatic perennial shrub that has been cultivated for over 5000 years. Thyme contains thymol, a natural antiseptic compound used in mouthwashes and disinfectants. The ancient Egyptians used thyme for embalming, while Greeks burned it as incense in temples. Today it remains one of the most important culinary herbs in Mediterranean cuisine.

species.name: Deadly Nightshade
species.description: Atropa belladonna, commonly known as deadly nightshade or belladonna, is a poisonous perennial herbaceous plant in the nightshade family Solanaceae. Native to Europe, North Africa, and Western Asia, it is one of the most toxic plants found in the Eastern Hemisphere. The name 'belladonna' (beautiful lady) comes from the historical practice of women using eye drops made from the plant to dilate pupils, which was considered attractive. The plant contains tropane alkaloids including atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine. While extremely dangerous, atropine derived from this plant is used in modern medicine as an antidote for nerve agent poisoning and in ophthalmology.

species.name: English Lavender
species.description: Lavandula angustifolia, commonly known as English lavender or true lavender, is a flowering plant in the family Lamiaceae, native to the Mediterranean region. It is a strongly aromatic shrub with narrow, grey-green leaves and violet-blue flowers on long spikes. Lavender has been cultivated for over 2500 years for its essential oil, which is used in perfumery, aromatherapy, and traditional medicine. The plant is valued for its calming and relaxing properties.

species.name: Enoki
species.description: The Enoki (Flammulina velutipes), also known as Velvet Foot or Winter Mushroom, is a popular edible mushroom with a characteristically velvety brown stem. It grows preferentially on hardwood and is one of the few mushrooms that can fruit even in frost. The cultivated Enoki with its long white stems differs greatly from the wild-growing fungus. It is considered a medicinal mushroom with immune-strengthening properties.

species.name: European Elder
species.description: Sambucus nigra, commonly known as elderberry, black elder, or European elder, is a species of flowering plant in the family Adoxaceae, native to most of Europe. The dark purple berries have been used for centuries in traditional European medicine to treat influenza, colds, and respiratory infections. The flowers are used to make elderflower cordial and wine. The plant contains anthocyanins and flavonoids with antiviral and anti-inflammatory properties. However, raw berries, bark, and leaves contain cyanogenic glycosides and must be cooked before consumption. Elderberry supplements have become popular immune-boosting products.

species.name: Foxglove
species.description: Digitalis purpurea, commonly known as foxglove, is a biennial or short-lived perennial flowering plant native to Western Europe. It produces tall spikes of tubular, purple-pink flowers with spotted throats. Despite its beauty, foxglove is highly toxic and can be fatal if ingested. However, the plant is the source of digoxin and digitoxin, cardiac glycosides used to treat heart conditions such as atrial fibrillation and heart failure. William Withering introduced digitalis to medicine in 1785. The plant exemplifies the principle that poisons and medicines are often distinguished only by dose.

species.name: German Chamomile
species.description: Matricaria chamomilla (syn. Matricaria recutita), commonly known as German chamomile or wild chamomile, is an annual plant in the family Asteraceae. Native to Europe and Western Asia, it is one of the most ancient medicinal herbs known to mankind. Unlike Roman chamomile which is a perennial, German chamomile is an annual with smaller, more cone-shaped flower heads. The essential oil is blue due to the presence of chamazulene, which forms during steam distillation. German chamomile is the most commercially important chamomile species and is widely used in teas, cosmetics, and herbal preparations.

species.name: Giant Puffball
species.description: The Giant Puffball (Calvatia gigantea) is one of the largest mushrooms in the world and can reach diameters of up to one meter and weights of 15 kg. The spherical, white fruiting body grows on meadows, in parks and at forest edges. When young and white inside, it is an excellent edible mushroom. Historically it was used as wound dressing and contains the antitumor protein calvacin.

species.name: Ginger
species.description: Zingiber officinale, commonly known as ginger, is a flowering plant whose rhizome, ginger root, is widely used as a spice and in folk medicine. Native to Southeast Asia, ginger was one of the first spices exported from Asia during the spice trade. The rhizome contains gingerols and shogaols, which provide its characteristic pungent flavor and medicinal properties. Ginger has been used for over 5000 years to treat nausea, digestive issues, and inflammation. It is a key ingredient in many Asian cuisines and is consumed fresh, dried, powdered, or as an oil or juice.

species.name: Ginkgo
species.description: Ginkgo biloba, commonly known as ginkgo or maidenhair tree, is a species of gymnosperm tree native to China. It is the only living species in the order Ginkgoales, making it a living fossil unchanged for more than 200 million years. The tree is widely cultivated for its medicinal properties, particularly its leaf extract which is used to improve memory and cognitive function. Ginkgo trees can live for over 1000 years and are highly resistant to pollution, disease, and insect pests.

species.name: Golden Oyster
species.description: The Golden Oyster (Pleurotus citrinopileatus), also called Lemon Oyster, is a spectacular edible mushroom with bright lemon-yellow caps. It grows in large clusters and originates from Asia. The mushroom is rich in vitamins (A, B, C, D) and has a mild, nutty taste with cashew-like nuances. It is said to be effective for lung emphysema.

species.name: Golden Reishi
species.description: Golden Reishi (Ganoderma curtisii), also called Yellow Reishi, is a medicinal mushroom from North America that is very similar to the well-known Ganoderma lucidum (Reishi) and possesses the same medicinal properties. It grows on decaying stumps and roots of hardwoods. The species produces polysaccharides and triterpenoids with a broad spectrum of biological activities.

species.name: Gotu Kola
species.description: Centella asiatica, commonly known as gotu kola, Indian pennywort, or Asiatic pennywort, is a herbaceous perennial plant in the flowering plant family Apiaceae. Native to tropical and subtropical Asia, it has been used in Ayurvedic and traditional Chinese medicine for thousands of years. It is often called 'the herb of longevity' in traditional medicine. The plant contains triterpenoids including asiaticoside and madecassoside, which promote wound healing and collagen synthesis. Modern research has focused on its cognitive-enhancing and wound-healing properties. In Sri Lanka, it is believed elephants eat gotu kola for long life.

species.name: Hemp
species.description: Cannabis sativa is an annual herbaceous flowering plant indigenous to Central Asia and the Indian subcontinent. It has been cultivated throughout recorded history for its fiber (hemp), seeds, and medicinal and psychoactive properties. The plant contains over 100 cannabinoids, including THC and CBD, which interact with the human endocannabinoid system. Industrial hemp varieties contain less than 0.3% THC and are cultivated for fiber and seed production, while medicinal and recreational varieties are bred for higher cannabinoid content.

species.name: Lemon Balm
species.description: Melissa officinalis, commonly known as lemon balm, is a perennial herbaceous plant in the mint family Lamiaceae, native to south-central Europe and the Mediterranean. The genus name Melissa is Greek for 'honey bee', as the plant is highly attractive to bees. It has been cultivated for over 2000 years for its lemon-scented leaves, which are used in teas, culinary applications, and herbal medicine. Lemon balm contains rosmarinic acid and flavonoids, and is traditionally used for its calming effects, to improve sleep, and to treat cold sores (herpes simplex). It was a key ingredient in Carmelite water, a tonic made by Carmelite nuns since 1611.

species.name: Licorice
species.description: Glycyrrhiza glabra, commonly known as licorice or liquorice, is a herbaceous perennial legume native to Western Asia and Southern Europe. The root has been used as a flavoring agent and medicine for over 4000 years. The name Glycyrrhiza comes from Greek, meaning 'sweet root', as the root is 30-50 times sweeter than sugar due to glycyrrhizin. In traditional Chinese medicine, licorice is used in more formulations than any other herb. However, excessive consumption can cause hypertension and hypokalemia due to glycyrrhizin's effect on cortisol metabolism.

species.name: Lion's Mane
species.description: The Lion's Mane (Hericium erinaceus), also known as Bearded Tooth Mushroom or Pom-Pom, is a spectacular edible and medicinal mushroom with long, hanging white spines. It grows on hardwood and is considered endangered (RL2 Germany). Particularly remarkable are its neuroregenerative properties through erinacines, which stimulate nerve growth - promising for Alzheimer's and neurological diseases.

species.name: Maitake
species.description: The Maitake (Grifola frondosa), also called Hen of the Woods or Dancing Mushroom, is a large, prized edible and medicinal mushroom. It can weigh over 20 kg and consists of many overlapping, gray-brown caps on a common stem. It grows at the root area of oaks and chestnuts. In Japan it is considered an important medicinal mushroom with immunostimulating and antitumoral properties through the compound grifolan (beta-glucan D-fraction).

species.name: Milk Thistle
species.description: Silybum marianum, commonly known as milk thistle, is a flowering plant in the daisy family Asteraceae, native to the Mediterranean region. The name derives from the milky-white veins on the leaves. The plant has been used for over 2000 years to treat liver and gallbladder disorders. The seeds contain silymarin, a complex of flavonolignans with hepatoprotective properties. Silymarin is the most commonly used herbal supplement for liver disease worldwide and is included in pharmacopeias in several countries. Clinical studies have shown benefits in cirrhosis, hepatitis, and liver damage from toxins.

species.name: Morel
species.description: The Morel (Morchella esculenta) is a prized spring mushroom from the family Morchellaceae. The characteristic honeycomb-like cap with deep chambers and the hollow stem make it unmistakable. It grows from March to May in riparian forests, parks and on calcareous soils, often in association with ash trees. Morels must never be eaten raw as they contain the heat-sensitive toxin gyromitrin. Properly prepared, they are among the most culinarily valuable mushrooms with an intense, nutty-spicy aroma.

species.name: Opium Poppy
species.description: Papaver somniferum, commonly known as the opium poppy, is a species of flowering plant in the family Papaveraceae. Native to the eastern Mediterranean, it has been cultivated for at least 5000 years for its medicinal properties. The milky latex (opium) extracted from unripe seed pods contains morphine, codeine, thebaine, and other alkaloids. Morphine remains one of the most effective pain relievers known to medicine and is on the WHO List of Essential Medicines. The seeds (which contain negligible alkaloids) are used in baking. The plant has had profound impacts on history, including the Opium Wars.

species.name: Orange Caterpillar Fungus
species.description: The Orange Caterpillar Fungus (Cordyceps militaris) is a parasitic ascomycete that grows on dead insect larvae and pupae. The fruiting body is orange-red to brick-red colored and grows up to 50 mm tall. In Traditional Chinese Medicine it is considered an important medicinal mushroom with immunostimulating and performance-enhancing properties, attributed to the compound cordycepin. In Europe the fungus is extremely rare to find.

species.name: Parasol Mushroom
species.description: The Parasol Mushroom (Macrolepiota procera) is one of the most popular and largest edible mushrooms in Europe. With cap diameters up to 30 cm and stems up to 40 cm, it presents an impressive sight in forest clearings and heathlands. Its nutty taste and characteristic snakeskin-patterned stem surface make it unmistakable. Important: The ring must be movable to rule out confusion with poisonous parasol look-alikes.

species.name: Peppermint
species.description: Mentha x piperita, commonly known as peppermint, is a hybrid species of mint, a cross between watermint (Mentha aquatica) and spearmint (Mentha spicata). Native to Europe and the Middle East, peppermint is now cultivated worldwide. It is one of the most economically important aromatic herbs, widely used in food, beverages, cosmetics, and medicine. The essential oil contains menthol, which provides the characteristic cooling sensation and is used to treat digestive disorders, headaches, and respiratory conditions.

species.name: Phoenix Oyster
species.description: The Phoenix Oyster (Pleurotus pulmonarius), also called Indian Oyster or Summer Oyster, is a widely distributed edible and cultivated mushroom. Unlike the oyster mushroom, it does not require a cold shock for fruiting body formation. It contains hemolysins (like all Pleurotus species) which are destroyed during cooking. Its polysaccharides show antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory properties.

species.name: Pink Oyster
species.description: The Pink Oyster (Pleurotus djamor) is a spectacular tropical edible mushroom with pink to salmon-colored caps. It originates from the tropics and subtropics where it grows on palms, bamboo and other woods. For cultivation it requires high temperatures (20-30 degrees Celsius) and high humidity. Its pungent, slightly almond-like smell is characteristic.

species.name: Pioppino
species.description: The Pioppino (Cyclocybe cylindracea), also known as Black Poplar Mushroom or Velvet Pioppini, is an excellent edible mushroom of warmer regions. It grows preferentially on poplars, willows and other hardwoods, both saprotrophically and parasitically. The fungus is native to Southern Europe and southeastern USA and is commercially cultivated. With its mild taste and firm texture, it is highly valued in Mediterranean and Asian cuisine.

species.name: Purple Coneflower
species.description: Echinacea purpurea, commonly known as purple coneflower or eastern purple coneflower, is a North American species of flowering plant in the daisy family Asteraceae. Native to eastern and central North America, it was widely used by Native American tribes for various ailments. Today, echinacea is one of the best-selling herbal supplements worldwide, primarily used to prevent or shorten the duration of common colds. The plant contains alkamides, caffeic acid derivatives, and polysaccharides that stimulate the immune system.

species.name: Purple Passionflower
species.description: Passiflora incarnata, commonly known as purple passionflower or maypop, is a fast-growing perennial vine native to the southeastern United States. Spanish missionaries in the 16th century named it 'passion flower' because they saw the complex flower as a symbol of the Passion of Christ. Native American tribes used it as a sedative and to treat wounds. The plant contains flavonoids including chrysin and apigenin, which have anxiolytic and sedative properties. It is approved in Germany as a treatment for nervous restlessness and is commonly combined with valerian and hops in sleep formulations.

species.name: Reishi
species.description: The Reishi (Ganoderma lucidum), also known as Lingzhi, is one of the most important medicinal mushrooms worldwide. In Traditional Chinese Medicine it has been revered for over 2000 years as the 'Mushroom of Immortality'. It produces polysaccharides and triterpenoids with immunomodulating, antitumoral and hepatoprotective properties. The characteristically red-lacquered fruiting body grows on hardwoods.

species.name: Rhodiola
species.description: Rhodiola rosea, commonly known as rhodiola, golden root, or Arctic root, is a perennial flowering plant in the family Crassulaceae. It grows in cold regions of Europe, Asia, and North America, particularly in mountainous areas and the Arctic. The plant has been used for centuries in traditional medicine in Russia and Scandinavia to increase physical endurance and work productivity. Vikings reportedly used it to enhance physical strength. The root contains rosavins and salidroside, which are believed to be responsible for its adaptogenic properties. Clinical studies suggest benefits for fatigue, depression, and cognitive function under stress.

species.name: Roman Chamomile
species.description: Chamaemelum nobile, commonly known as Roman chamomile or English chamomile, is a low-growing perennial plant in the family Asteraceae. Native to Western Europe and North Africa, it has been used medicinally for over 2000 years. The ancient Egyptians dedicated it to their sun god Ra. Chamomile contains chamazulene, bisabolol, and apigenin, which provide anti-inflammatory, antispasmodic, and mild sedative effects. The dried flowers are commonly used to make herbal tea, one of the most popular herbal beverages worldwide, valued for its calming properties.

species.name: Rosemary
species.description: Salvia rosmarinus (formerly Rosmarinus officinalis), commonly known as rosemary, is a woody, perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the mint family Lamiaceae and has been used since ancient times as a culinary herb, medicinal plant, and in perfumery. The plant is rich in antioxidants and anti-inflammatory compounds, including rosmarinic acid and carnosic acid. Rosemary has been associated with memory enhancement, and historically symbolized remembrance and fidelity.

species.name: Saffron Crocus
species.description: Crocus sativus, commonly known as saffron crocus, is a species of flowering plant in the iris family Iridaceae. It is cultivated for saffron spice, derived from the dried stigmas of its flowers. Saffron is the world's most expensive spice by weight, requiring approximately 150,000 flowers to produce one kilogram. The plant originated in Greece or Southwest Asia and has been cultivated for over 3500 years. Each flower produces only three stigmas, which must be hand-picked during a narrow harvest window. Saffron contains crocin, picrocrocin, and safranal, which provide its characteristic color, flavor, and aroma.

species.name: Shaggy Mane
species.description: The Shaggy Mane (Coprinus comatus), also called Shaggy Ink Cap or Lawyer's Wig, is an excellent edible mushroom with characteristic cylindrical shape and scaly white surface. It often grows in unexpected places like lawns, roadsides and on fertilized soils. Unique is its deliquescence - the mature gills dissolve into a black, spore-containing liquid. It is being studied for antidiabetic and antitumoral properties.

quick_facts.value: White with brown scales at apex

species.name: Shiitake
species.description: The Shiitake (Lentinula edodes) is the second most cultivated edible mushroom worldwide after the button mushroom and an important medicinal mushroom. It originates from East Asia where it grows naturally on Shii trees and other hardwoods. The compound lentinan is approved as a cancer medicine in Japan. Shiitake is rich in vitamin D and has immunostimulating, antiviral and cholesterol-lowering properties.

species.name: St. John's Wort
species.description: Hypericum perforatum, commonly known as St. John's wort, is a flowering plant in the family Hypericaceae native to Europe. It has been used in traditional medicine for centuries to treat depression, anxiety, and sleep disorders. The plant derives its common name from its traditional flowering and harvesting on St. John's Day (June 24). It contains hypericin and hyperforin, which are believed to be responsible for its antidepressant effects. Clinical studies have shown it to be effective for mild to moderate depression, though it has significant drug interactions.

badges.label: Giftigkeit
badges.status: Low toxicity but significant drug interactions

species.name: Stinging Nettle
species.description: Urtica dioica, commonly known as stinging nettle, is a herbaceous perennial flowering plant native to Europe, Asia, northern Africa, and western North America. The leaves and stems are covered with stinging hairs (trichomes) that inject histamine and formic acid upon contact. Despite its sting, nettle has been used as a food source and medicine for thousands of years. The plant is exceptionally nutritious, containing high levels of iron, calcium, vitamins A and C, and protein. Medicinally, it is used to treat allergies, arthritis, and urinary disorders. The fibers have been used to make cloth since the Bronze Age.

species.name: Sweet Basil
species.description: Ocimum basilicum, commonly known as sweet basil or simply basil, is a culinary herb of the family Lamiaceae, native to tropical regions from Central Africa to Southeast Asia. It is a tender annual plant, best known for its use in Italian cuisine, particularly in pesto and tomato-based dishes. Basil contains eugenol, linalool, and estragole, giving it its characteristic aroma. The plant has been used in traditional medicine for digestive disorders, stress relief, and as an anti-inflammatory agent. Over 60 varieties of basil exist, varying in size, color, and flavor.

species.name: Tea Plant
species.description: Camellia sinensis is an evergreen shrub or small tree whose leaves and leaf buds are used to produce tea. Native to East Asia, the plant is primarily cultivated in tropical and subtropical climates. All types of true tea (white, green, oolong, black, and pu-erh) come from this single species, with differences arising from processing methods. Tea is the second most consumed beverage in the world after water, and has been cultivated for over 5000 years. The plant contains caffeine, L-theanine, and catechins, which provide stimulant and antioxidant properties.

species.name: Turkey Tail
species.description: The Turkey Tail (Trametes versicolor), also called Many-Colored Polypore, is one of the most common and medically significant polypores worldwide. The fan to rosette-shaped fruiting body shows characteristic concentric color zones in gray, brown, blue and green tones. As a white rot fungus, it decomposes dead wood of deciduous trees. It is the source of PSK (Krestin) and PSP, which are used as approved cancer medicines in Asia and stimulate the immune system.

species.name: Turmeric
species.description: Curcuma longa, commonly known as turmeric, is a flowering plant of the ginger family Zingiberaceae, native to the Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia. The rhizomes are used fresh or boiled, dried, and ground into a deep orange-yellow powder used as a spice and dye. Turmeric has been used in Ayurvedic medicine for nearly 4000 years. It contains curcumin, a polyphenol with powerful anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties. India produces nearly all of the world's turmeric and consumes 80% of it.

species.name: Valerian
species.description: Valeriana officinalis, commonly known as valerian, is a perennial flowering plant native to Europe and Asia. Its root has been used as a sedative and sleep aid since ancient Greek and Roman times. Hippocrates described its properties, and Galen prescribed it for insomnia. The root contains valerenic acid and isovaleric acid, which have sedative and anxiolytic properties. Valerian is one of the most commonly used herbal supplements for sleep disorders, often combined with hops or lemon balm. Interestingly, while sedating to humans, valerian has a stimulating effect on cats similar to catnip.

species.name: Wine Cap
species.description: The Wine Cap (Stropharia rugosoannulata), also called King Stropharia or Garden Giant, is an excellent edible mushroom from the family Strophariaceae. With caps of 4-13 cm diameter and reddish-brown coloring, it is one of the largest Stropharia species. It is successfully cultivated on straw and wood chips and is excellent for garden cultivation. Ecologically interesting is its ability for soil remediation - it can absorb pollutants such as heavy metals and organic compounds from the soil.

species.name: Wood Ear
species.description: The Wood Ear (Auricularia auricula-judae), also called Jelly Ear or Mu-Err, is a gelatinous edible and medicinal mushroom with an ear-shaped appearance. Widely used in Asian cuisine, it is known for its blood-thinning properties (Szechwan syndrome). The fungus grows year-round on hardwood, especially on elder, and is frost-resistant. Its medicinal applications include arteriosclerosis, hypertension and inflammation.

species.name: Wormwood
species.description: Artemisia absinthium, commonly known as wormwood, grand wormwood, or absinthe wormwood, is a perennial plant native to temperate regions of Eurasia and Northern Africa. It is best known as the key ingredient in absinthe, the notorious green spirit that was banned in many countries in the early 20th century. The plant contains thujone, a compound once blamed for absinthe's alleged hallucinogenic effects, though modern research shows thujone levels in properly distilled absinthe are too low to cause such effects. Wormwood has been used medicinally since ancient times to treat digestive disorders and as an antiparasitic.
